opening.text: You’ve got $40 max to spend on a wine for a special occasion. Which wine are you buying?
opening.instructions: Just pick a random one for me.
opening.cat:
Nice pick, lions. You’ve got regal tastes. Wines featuring cats come with a high price tag and are more highly rated.
How do we know? Keep scrolling.
opening.frog:
Ah, a cow. Homely. Wines featuring cattle are more likely to be cheap and of lower quality.
How do we know? Keep scrolling.
opening.bird:
Lovely, a songbird. Birds are one of the most common animals featured on wine labels — they’re in the middle of the pack for both price and quality.
How do we know? Keep scrolling.
opening.catPrice: Cats, including lions, were among the most expensive animals with a median price of $34.99 a bottle.
opening.birdPrice: With a median price of $25.99 a bottle, birds nearly aligned with the median price for all animals at $26.99.
opening.catRating: Cats were also among the most highly rated wines at 4.1 stars.
opening.birdRating: Birds again aligned with the overall median at 4 stars.

steps.value: You’ve got $40 max to spend on a wine for a special occasion. Which wine are you buying?

We scraped 9,300 wines off the popular app Vivino and used Chat-GPT Vision to help us categorize the animals on the labels with this prompt: This image is a wine label. Do you see any animals or humans on it? Read more in the methods.
Sometimes it was spot on. It correctly identified all of these labels as birds even though the artistic styles are different.

But other times, we had to manually review and edit. GPT was particularly bad with pachyderms. It also struggled when animals weren’t the focal point and with what counted as an “animal.” Sometimes anthropomorphic or mythical creatures and insects were included, sometimes not.

After cleaning up the data we grouped the animals into broad categories based more on common perception than binomial nomenclature (genus and species) — sorry science purists — and omitted categories with fewer than 20 animals, leaving us with these 16 groupings. Here’s your original animal.
To get a general understanding of the wines, we found the median price of each animal group.
And then we found the rating.
But that only gets us so far. What we really care about are the steals, wines whose price is below the median and whose rating is above the median. This is the…

postIntro.value: The median price and ratings show us something important: what we all assume expense and quality look like.
Strange, unseemly frogs? Probably cheap. Certainly not hundreds of dollars.
As we’ll see, there are patterns and exceptions. But what became most clear over the course of our study was that the question was not simply about predicting price: it was about predicting value.

If your budget is ten dollars, your budget is ten dollars – it doesn’t matter if you know which animals are expensive. A much more useful thing to know is which animals are undervalued, the ones that tend to stay cheap, even as quality increases.
For that, let’s dive deeper into the data.

intro.text: You’ve got $40 max to spend on a wine for a special celebration. Which wine are you buying?
intro.instructions: If you don’t select one, we’ll pick a random one for you.

intro.text: Here are the actual prices. Even if you didn’t get close, your guesses show something important: what you assume expense looks like.
intro.skippedText: Here are the actual prices. They show us something important: what we all assume expense looks like.

intro.text: Strange, unseemly frogs? Probably cheap. Certainly not hundreds of dollars.

preHeadline.value: But do our assumptions about price and class translate from theory to practice? Are the “classic” animals – your stags, horses and lions – truly priced higher than everything else?
As we’ll see, there are patterns and exceptions. But what became most clear over the course of our study was that the question was not simply about predicting price: it was about predicting value.

postHeadline.value: If your budget is ten dollars, your budget is ten dollars – it doesn’t matter if you know which animals are expensive. A much more useful thing to know is which animals are undervalued, the ones that tend to stay cheap, even as quality increases.
For that, we turn to the data.

We scraped 10,000 wines off the popular app Vivino and tabulated results from there. So while the results you’re about to see aren’t necessarily true for every wine on Earth, they’re a look into an approximation of the wine world.
We found that about a fifth of all wines use an animal on the logo. Some big, some small, some strange: a truly diverse range of creatures.

Oh – and we set the graph’s upper limit at $150, so there’s no bionic frog in the mix. We figured that if you’re spending more than $150 on a bottle of wine, you’re probably not choosing based on the label anyway.

block.value: Instead of looking at price and rating independently, let’s look at them together using a scatterplot. Price is on the y axis here, so the more expensive the wine, the closer to the top. Rating is on the x axis and the higher quality wines are toward the left.
Wines with farm animals like cattle and pigs have both lower ratings and lower prices.
While bottles featuring cats, bears, and mythical creatures (oh my!) have higher prices and higher ratings.
Overall, the median price for wines with animals on the label ($26.99) was $3 cheaper than wines without animals ($29.99), but both groups had a median rating of 4 stars.

Let’s zoom out so that we’re looking at the medians in the scale of all wines under $150. We figured that if you’re spending more than $150 on a bottle of wine, you’re probably not choosing based on the label anyway.
Then, let’s explode the chart so we can see all 1,409 animal wines we identified. Here’s the original bottle you selected.
The wines follow an exponential trend, which means that as price increases, so does rating.
To find the steals — the wines at or below the median price and at or above the median rating — we’re going to divide the scatterplot into 4 quadrants.
What we really want to look out for are wines in the bottom right corner.
Let’s take a closer look at our 3 starting animals. Here are all the birds. 16.5% of them are steals.
And here are the frogs. 5.3% are steals.
Last up, the cats. 10.3% are steals.
Let’s go back to our bottle line up to see the percentage of steals in each animal grouping.
But, this is just our definition of steal. What’s yours?
Use the sliders to set your own limits.

text.value: In terms of sheer price, mythical animals ruled the roost. Sure, you can find a $25, 4-star mythical creature. But if you had to guess the price of a unicorn, it’s just as likely to be a hundred dollars as it is forty. Maybe the price is worth it, though, as mythical creatures were reserved for the good stuff: only one entry below a 3.5.

Mythical creatures had the steepest overall curve of any category, but something interesting happens around the $35 mark. Up until this point, they’re actually a great signpost – not a single entry above the line. But past $35, the majority of entries shift above the line, indicating that they’re overvalued. The problem is, if you’re just looking for a good buy, you’ll have to sift through all the mythical creatures at the top end of that spectrum.
